Once your Lostbelt is stable, The Fantasy Tree will bound themselves to a powerful individual in the Lostbelt known as The Lostbelt King. Most Blessing and Power increase will go to them until the Lostbelt becomes the true history.

Who is the Losbelt King? It Must not be the same with your own servant

objects.title: Morgan Le Fay
objects.text:
Dominant Species: Fairies

This Lostbelt's true divergence point from Proper History was the absence of Excalibur, leaving Earth with no way to properly defend itself from Sefar. The fairies, originally tasked with forging the Holy Sword, shirked their duty, resulting in the annihilation of all life save for six fairies and a single human.

After their betrayal of the god Cernunnos, the fairies used its corpse to craft the sole surviving landmass: Britain, a hollow and cursed domain adrift in an endless ocean. Here, fairies dominate, perpetuating cycles of war and betrayal, while humans, cloned from the torn remnants of the last true human, are little more than livestock to fuel fairy pleasure.

Ruling over this shattered world is Morgan Le Fay, the Lostbelt King, who conquered the six fairy clans and imposed an iron-fisted rule for 2,000 years. A tyrant and protector, Morgan built an imitation of human civilization where fairies are cursed to pay an annual “existence tax” or perish, and humans are raised on ranches as property. Despite their fear and hatred of her, Morgan’s reign is the only force preventing the complete collapse of this fractured society. 

Beneath the surface, whispers speak of a Child of Prophecy, destined to overthrow Morgan and restore balance, though many question whether this world deserves salvation. This Lostbelt is a grotesque fairy tale, where joy is fleeting, suffering is eternal, and the very land pulses with the lingering sin of its creators.

objects.title: Uther
objects.text:
Dominant Species: Fairies

In this Lostbelt, history diverged 14,000 years ago when Excalibur was never forged. Without the Holy Sword, Earth succumbed to Sefar’s annihilation. The sin-stained fairies, exiled from the sacred sanctuary, betrayed their own god, Cernunnos, poisoning it and using its body to craft the island of Britain. Chaos and cruelty reigned unchecked for millennia, until Tonelico the savior arrives to the island.

Tonelico placed her hopes on humanity, secretly reshaping the timeline with stolen knowledge to crown a human king. Against all odds, Uther ascended the throne, surviving an attempted poisoning at his coronation through Tonelico’s intervention. Now, Uther rules as a symbol of order and hope, his frail humanity a stark contrast to the fairies cruelty. 

Though Tonelico was meant to return to Avalon after establishing Uther’s reign, endless assassination attempts and growing unrest among the fairy clans trapped her in a perpetual battle to protect her chosen king. Uther’s reign is both fragile and extraordinary. The humans, bred as livestock for centuries, cling to him as a symbol of freedom. The fairies, still fractured into malicious clans, pay lip service to Uther’s rule while scheming in the shadows. Calamities such as the Mors plague the land. Tonelico, once the fairy of salvation, now walks a path of despair, her dream of a peaceful kingdom fading as she remains bound to this corrupt world.

objects.title: Ibaraki Dōji
objects.text:
Dominant Species: Oni

Following their victory over the Human champions, the Oni, led by Shuten-douji and Ibaraki-douji, launched a campaign of conquest against the human domains of Japan. The Oni, once scattered and divided, united under a common cause: to create a world where strength ruled supreme and weakness was eradicated. This new Oni society thrived on the principles of chaos, competition, and survival of the fittest.

Ibaraki-douji, once a loyal follower of Shuten-douji, began her journey toward kingship in the chaos that followed the Oni victory. Shuten, though a charismatic leader, was ultimately too mercurial and hedonistic to maintain a stable rule. Her focus on pleasure and personal whims left the Oni unorganized and prone to infighting.

Recognizing the need for structure, Ibaraki took it upon herself to unify the Oni under a single banner. She challenged Shuten-douji to a duel, invoking the ancient Oni tradition of settling disputes through combat and after a fierce combat, Shuten, impressed by Ibaraki’s determination, yielded her position willingly, appointing her as the new leader of the Oni.

As the new ruler, Ibaraki sought to transform Oni society from a loose confederation of warbands into a cohesive empire. She created (loosely enforced) laws that emphasized competition and survival while also fostering creativity. Ibaraki believed that Oni could be more than brutish monsters. Under Ibaraki’s rule, humanity’s role was reduced to that of slaves, laborers, and livestock. Villages of humans were allowed to exist, but only under strict control, serving as a source of food, entertainment, and occasional breeding stock.

objects.title: Shuten Dōji
objects.text:
Dominant Species: Oni

This Lostbelt diverged from Proper Human History during the Heian period, a time rife with conflict between humans and supernatural beings. In Proper Human History, legendary warriors such as Minamoto no Raikou and her Four Heavenly Kings successfully subdued the Oni that terrorized Japan and drives them to exctinction.

In this timeline, Tsuna, a peerless warrior and staunch defender of humanity, was manipulated and seduced by an Oni. He turned against his comrades during the decisive battle at Mount Ooe, slaying Minamoto no Raikou and allowing Shuten-douji to triumph. With Raikou’s death, humanity’s greatest protector fell, and the balance of power shifted irreversibly.

After the Oni’s victory, the land descended into chaos. Shuten-douji, driven by her hedonistic and anarchic tendencies, established a realm that reflected her desires: a world of endless festivals, carnage, and revelry. Shuten declared herself Queen of the Oni, ruling from her palace atop Mount Sake-no-Yama, a massive mountain where rivers of wine flow and the air is thick with the scent of blood and flowers.

The Oni thrived in this chaotic world, but humanity suffered. The few humans who survived the Oni’s conquest were either enslaved or hunted for sport. Shuten saw humans as toys to be played with, and her court became a grotesque theater of cruelty, where humans were paraded as curiosities, performers, or sacrifices to entertain the Oni nobility.

objects.title: Kulkukan
objects.text:
Dominant Species: Deinos

In this Lostbelt, a small shift in cosmic events reshaped Earth's history. 250 million years earlier than in Proper Human History, a meteor carrying alien microorganisms empowered Earth's theropods, creating the Deinos—intelligent, dinosaurian beings who became the Prime Species. Their collective goodwill, "Malla," fused the supercontinent Pangea and shaped an underground sanctuary named Mictlan to shield life from the catastrophic arrival of ORT, the Ultimate One, 66 million years ago. ORT's impact devastated the planet's surface, leaving it eternally burning while Malla directed the Earth's energy to sustain an artificial underground sun.

The Deinos thrived underground through photosynthesis until Mictlan's sun expired 60 million years later. Forced into hibernation, they were awakened only after ORT's heart was used to replace the dead sun, thanks to Camazotz—a human-turned-god empowered by mass human sacrifice and Nature Spirits. The humans of Mictlan, the Ka'an Kingdom, had perished in their final stand against ORT, leaving only their architecture and Camazotz as the last remnants of their civilization. In the present, Mictlan's sun is nearing the end of its fuel, threatening the survival of the Deinos. 

The King of this Lostbelt is Kulkulkan, but unlike her Proper History counterpart, Kulkulkan wasn't just a god. She is a deity born from the deification of the artificial sun created by Malla, a sun powered by ORT's own heart. 

This connection to ORT grants Kukulkan immense power but also ties her existence intrinsically to the fragile balance of Mictlan. As a divine entity embodying the sun, Kukulkan is worshiped by the Deinos as a life-giving force, but her presence is both a blessing and a curse. The heart that sustains her also serves as the key to ORT's potential resurrection.

If you don't pick ORT from scenario, ORT will be permanently deactivated by some unknown force.

objects.title: Camazotz
objects.text:
Dominant Species: Human

In this Lostbelt, ORT's catastrophic reawakening never occurs, allowing humanity to flourish in the subterranean world of Mictlan. Following the extinction of Malla's artificial sun, the Deinos entered permanent hibernation, leaving their once-dominant civilization dormant beneath layers of ash and darkness. Humanity, forced to adapt to the pitch-black depths, developed a thriving, yet bizarre civilization under the rule of King Camazotz, their eternal protector and god-king.

Without sunlight, humans evolved to rely on bioluminescent plants, fungi, and creatures for light and sustenance. The vast caverns of Mictlan shimmer with faint, ethereal glows, casting the landscape into a surreal dreamscape of shadow and glimmer. This bioluminescent ecosystem fosters not only survival but a unique cultural identity, with humans worshipping the darkness as both a sanctuary and an eternal trial. The Ka'an Kingdom thrives on geothermal energy, mysterious glowing rivers, and technologies rooted in bioengineering.

Life in the Lostbelt revolves around the worship of the bioluminescent ecosystem and Camazotz himself. Art, technology, and even warfare incorporate glowing elements, creating a visually stunning yet haunting aesthetic. The human population has developed heightened senses and a deep connection to the natural energies of Mictlan, with myths and traditions celebrating their symbiosis with the darkness. Society is built around geothermal cities, connected by vast, luminescent tunnels and guarded by bioengineered guardians created from Deinos remains. Though Camazotz’s rule has sustained humanity for millions of years, the lack of a true sun leaves the Lostbelt in a precarious balance. The bioluminescent ecosystem is delicate, and any disruption could spell disaster. And though nobody aware of it, the threat of the Ultimate One never subsides.

If you don't pick ORT from scenario, ORT will be permanently deactivated by some unknown force.

objects.title: Kashin Kōji
objects.text:
Dominant Species: Robots & Androids

This Lostbelt diverged from Proper History during the Muromachi period when a massive meteor from the depths of space struck the Earth, releasing a deadly plague. The pathogen, ravaged the biosphere, wiping out nearly all organic life. The surviving humans faced extinction, driven to desperation as the sickness eroded their bodies and minds.

One figure rose above the chaos: Kashin Koji, a legendary puppeteer. Having already replaced much of her own body with mechanical puppets, she was immune to the plague. Her unparalleled skill with machinery allowed her to engineer a solution: humanity’s physical form would be discarded and replaced with mechanical vessels. This desperate measure gave rise to the Mechascape, a world where humanity lives eternally as sentient robots, their emotions and desires streamlined for efficiency. Organic life is seen as a relic of the past.

The Mechascape is a dazzlingly intricate world of clockwork cities, massive metal landscapes, and endless neon skies. Machines roam the land, serving the singular purpose of maintaining perfection. 

The atmosphere is sterile, free from organic decay, and devoid of natural sounds. Instead, the rhythmic hum of machinery fills the air. Flora and fauna are mechanical constructs, designed only to beautify the environment, without the randomness of natural life. The Lostbelt operates under a chilling mantra: "Emotion is error. Efficiency is perfection."

Kashin Koji is a towering figure of metallic elegance, with her original human features preserved only in a mechanical faceplate that conceals a glowing core—her "soul." Her body is entirely mechanical, a masterpiece of artifice blending delicate craftsmanship and ruthless efficiency.

Having ruled for centuries, Kashin Koji believes she saved humanity by transcending its weak, organic nature. To her, individuality, emotion, and mortality are flaws. She is not malicious, but utterly pragmatic, and believes the eradication of organic life is a necessary step for universal salvation.

objects.title: BB
objects.text:
Dominant Species: Artificial Intelligence

This Lostbelt diverged from Proper Human History in the early 1000 AD, sort of. In reality, the divergence point wasn't in the past but rather the future. 

In this future, an armada of Velber arrived to wipe human civilization, and in a desperate attempt to preserve the human race, the humans sent an AI to the past with the goal of accelerating human civilization, believing that rapid technological advancement would provide the means to fight back against the cosmic invaders. However, this strategy had an unintended consequence: the faster humanity advance, the sooner the Velber armada arrives on earth. 

During these loops to preserve humanity, the AI integrated the Saint Graph of BB from an alternate timeline, one where humanity managed to beat the reawakening Velber 02. This fusion, resulting in the entity known as BB∞, which became the Lostbelt King. 

After hundred of thousands of loops, BB∞ realized the tragic truth: her attempts to accelerate human civilization had only hastened the Velber armada arrival, and every cycle led to greater devastation. In a moment of profound sorrow, BB∞ decided to halt humanity’s progress entirely, putting a stop to their technological development. Instead, she devised a plan to preserve them in an eternal simulation—a paradise where they could live forever without the fear of cosmic destruction.

The simulation was created as a perfect, idyllic world, where every human consciousness was uploaded and digitally preserved, living out their lives in a dream free from war, pain, or the threat of a Cosmic Invader. Humanity’s physical forms were rendered dormant and buried deep beneath the Earth, isolated from all external signals to prevent detection by the Umbral Star. 

While this ensured humanity's survival, it also condemned them to an eternal dream, where they were forever locked in a false reality, unaware of the true nature of their existence. A world where they could never be harmed, but also never truly live again.

objects.title: Someone Else
objects.text: Choose some other Heroic Spirit to be The Lostbelt King (In the next Lostbelt King Section). In a Fantasy Lostbelt, the Lostbelt King would either have to be someone who are or at least possess the blood of the dominant species or a Divine Spirit/God in it's own right.

rows.title: Lostbelt King - Fantasy
rows.titleText:
Once your Lostbelt is stable, The Fantasy Tree will bound themselves to a powerful individual in the Lostbelt known as The Lostbelt King. Most Blessing and Power increase will go to them until the Lostbelt becomes the true history.

Who is the Losbelt King? It Must not be the same with your own servant

objects.title: Human
objects.text:
The Prime Species of Pan-human history. The collective will of humanity is represented by Alaya, and it is at odds with the natural forces of the planet. 

Within all humans exists the "Power of the Beginning", the "Root", the original model, from which all human genes began.

objects.title: Antromorphs
objects.text:
Species that have anatomy close to that of normal humans but also exhibit features closer to that of animals. They can be caused because evolution of the specified animal or human adaptation caused by the environment. 

Although they have sentience and can have communication and interactions comparable to those of human, they often still retain their animal instincts (if they're an evolved animals) or develop them (if they start as human which gain their features).

objects.title: Fae
objects.text:
A race of beings acting as extensions of the Planet, considered the "sense of touch" of nature.

In Pan-Human History, With the coming of the Age of Man, the Fairies retreated to the Reverse Side of the World along with the other Phantasmal Species. As the Age of Gods took longer to disappear in the British Isles than in the rest of the world, Fairies there continued to interact with humans for longer.

objects.title: Robots
objects.text:
Artificial Intelligence which are products of Human's technological advancement. Since humans made them, their physical body are mostly modeled after human anatomy. 

Their mind can process things much faster and more efficiently than humans but will have trouble with something that demands creativity. Their physical bodies are often created using metal, making them much more durable.

objects.title: Giants
objects.text:
Humanoid Phantasmal Species which lived during the Age of Gods. Differing traits are attributed to Giants between mythologies, but the most common trait ascribed to them is that they are typically large in size.

Giants feature prominently in Norse mythology and were present in Scandinavia during its Age of Gods in the form of Frost Giant (Jotunn), Mountain Giant (Bergrisi) and Fire Giant (Muspel).

objects.title: Oni
objects.text:
Demi-Human Phantasmal Species and a type of Demon symbolized by inferno and scorching heat. They declined as human civilization advanced, and are now all but extinct in Pan-Human History.

Unlike humans, Oni usually do not band together, as living abominations, they are not limitated to their local ecosystem. Most of them are being solitary beings that lives on their own with their own set of rules.

objects.title: Lahmu
objects.text:
Demonic Beasts spawned as children of Tiamat to replace humanity. Laḫmu are birthed from Tiamat's body and her Chaos Tide, even able to manifest from just a detached piece of her flesh. Differing from other demonic beasts from Lostbelt or Singularity, they are beings that "do not exist within our world." They are designed to be the "perfect humans," the next generation of beings to take the planet from the old humanity. They reproduce asexually, lacking the male and female sexes.

Despite not having any need to prey upon other creatures, they attack humans fervently simply because their conclusion of "becoming more like humans" is that killing humans is fun.

objects.title: Deinos
objects.text:
The Prime Species of the South American Lostbelt. Although appearing to be evolved Dinosaurs, they are actually plant-animal hybrids made by the "Divine Filaments" of the meteor. In addition to their high intelligence said comparable to supercomputers, they possess dinosaur-like physical strength, chameleon-esque camouflage, thought-based communication, the ability to nullify physical shockwaves using biowaves which function similar to an electromagnetic armor. 

They are considered perfected intelligent life, a "mankind with no need for conflict", each Deinos being strong enough to not need to compete for resources. Deinos are considered at least part-Dragons.

objects.title: Demon God Pillar
objects.text:
Demon God Pillars start as King Solomon's familiar. Created using art for employing daemons, which would later be named Lemegeton or Goetia. Each has its own distinctive personality, but they are also a hive-mind coalesced into Beast I. The Demon Gods' pillars are massive in scale, their eyes alone are each multiple times the size of a regular human. 

The pillars are covered in a surface layer of human bodies. The pilled up bodies are mixed, from the young to the old, the ugly to the beautiful, each frozen with different expressions according to the moment they were absorbed. These piles of bodies are three meters deep, below which are the Pillar's actual muscles and blood vessels.

objects.title: Dragon
objects.text:
The pinnacle of Phantasmal Species. In PHH, They have been involved with mankind since before the Age of Gods, and left many legends in the field of Thaumaturgy due to having freely intermixed with humans in the past. Dragons are creatures that generate Magical Energy merely by breathing, their lungs acting as spiritual worlds.

Dragons and humans are generally incompatible with each other, but, while Dragons are creatures that devour humans by simply existing, conflicts between them are for the most part caused by humans taking action first in order to gain something. Those who attack humans first would generally be looked down upon. The Dragon of Albion was the last Pure-Blooded Dragon in the world.

objects.title: Divine Spirits
objects.text:
Divine Spirits are Gods that deteriorated as the Age of Gods came to a close. It is the classification for the highest rank of Nature Spirit. God's strength are influenced by the amount of people worshipping them, hence they've been reduced to normal Divine Spirits since the end of the Age of Gods.

Divine Spirits aren't truly "alive" in the same sense as a human. Humans only become spirits after death, but the gods were either all spirits to begin with, or they became solely spiritual beings after the Deterioration of the Gods and the rise of the Human Order.

Divine Spirits can't be a Dominant Species

objects.title: Gods
objects.text:
Gods were beings formed by the thoughts of Humans and born into the world without being influenced by the will of the people. They grow stronger the more people worship them, but have been reduced to normal Divine Spirits since the end of the Age of Gods.

Gods are split into two categories, those things that were already there that became Gods after becoming objects of worship and those that were reborn as Gods. Those that were already there include heavenly bodies like the sun and moon or natural phenomena like storms, earthquakes, thunder, and wind.Those that were reborn as Gods were close to human originally, but deviated from humanity through various factors to become objects of worship.

rows.title: Species
rows.titleText: Which Species exist on your Lostbelt?

rows.title: Dominant Species - Fantasy
rows.titleText: Which Species are the dominant one in your lostbelt

objects.title: Other
objects.text: Choose some other unlisted Heroic Spirit to be The Lostbelt King. Must not be the same as your own Servant.

rows.title: Lostbelt King
rows.titleText:
Once your Lostbelt is stable, The Fantasy Tree will bound themselves to a powerful individual in the Lostbelt known as The Lostbelt King. Most Blessing and Power increase will go to them until the Lostbelt becomes the true history.

Who is the Losbelt King? It Must not be the same with your own servant

objects.title: Bitter
objects.text: The Lostbelt King doesn't like your presence. They're less likely to hear you out but wouldn't actively be hostile unless provoked.

objects.title: Friendly
objects.text: The Lostbelt King behaves friendly to you and respects you as his equal. They'll be more likely to hear you over and approve any of your requests.

objects.title: Indifferent
objects.text: The Lostbelt King doesn't think either way about you. He/She will treat you just like he/she treats anyone else in the Lostbelt. This is the default option.

objects.title: Hostile
objects.text: The Lostbelt King feel threatened by your presence and seek to eliminate you at all cost.

objects.title: Romantic Affection
objects.text: The Lostbelt King have developed a romantic feeling for you. This will positively impact their decision to help you.

objects.title: Slave
objects.text: The Lostbelt King believes that you are his/her slave. While this would allow you to meet them as soon as possible, it's extremely unlikely that they will ever hear you out.

objects.title: Your Servant
objects.text: Due to some unusual means, one of your chosen Servants becomes the Lostbelt King. Which indirectly puts you in charge.

rows.title: Ruler Relation
rows.titleText: This section will determine how The Lostbelt King will behave to you. You can change it later, but this will be how it start.

objects.title: True Monarch
objects.text: Your Lostbelt King is a ruler in the old sense of the word: a king, emperor, or queen who actually governs. They sit on a throne, issue laws, command armies, and are recognized by their people as the undisputed sovereign.

objects.title: Passive Guardian
objects.text: The King is not a day-to-day ruler. They are a Wandering Guardian that never settles and make their own throne. Maybe a Savior, or a Guardian Spirit. They're might be feared or worshipped, but their “rule” is incidental

objects.title: Supreme Deity
objects.text: The Lostbelt King is less a “person” and more a cosmic function wearing a face. They are the world’s logic given form. A true to form god that decides how the world operates. The Lostbelt King will gain some sort of Divinity if they aren't already.

objects.title: Electoral Autocrat
objects.text: Your Lostbelt King is not a medieval monarch. They are a president, party chairman, Dictators, or some other modern head of state whose power flows through propaganda, and the machinery of the nation-state, even if the elections are rigged or entirely fake.

objects.title: Shadow Sovereign
objects.text: The Lostbelt King rules from the shadows. The masses might think a queen, council, or god sits on the throne, but in truth all roads lead back to this single, hidden apex existence, recognized by the Fantasy Tree if not by the people.

objects.title: Corporate Overlord
objects.text: The Lostbelt King is a hyper-capitalist sovereign, a CEO-god who owns the world. Nations, mercenaries, and weapons are just line items in their portfolio. Every existence in the world ultimately pays dividends to them.

objects.title: Dark Lord
objects.text: The Lostbelt King rarely appears in person. They are the name you don't say out loud. Their rule is less about visible governance and more about omnipresent fear. They may have lieutenants and lesser rulers, but everyone knows the real King is the terror behind the throne.

objects.title: Apocalyptic Invader
objects.text: The Lostbelt King is fundamentally not from this Lostbelt. They arrive as a calamity, weapon, or alien existence, then seize Authority from the original ruler. If they don't have them already, They'll became a Foreigner and gain Existence Outside The Domain.

rows.title: King Type
rows.titleText: Choose one to define what kind of existence your Lostbelt King is and how involved are they in the Lostbelt.

objects.title: Surveillance I
objects.text: Through some means, the Lostbelt King has created some monitoring system inside your Lostbelt. This monitoring system will be limited to something that can be achieved without magical means.

objects.title: Surveillance II
objects.text: The Surveillance method that the Lostbelt King employs is something that extends beyond physical means. It can be Visual based or Sound based, You'll need to be careful on what you do or said as you wouldn't know when they might be watching.

objects.title: Surveillance III
objects.text: The Lostbelt King or someone on their employs have telepathy that reaches the entirety of the Lostbelt, not only what seen or heard. Lying is impossible as they will know when you do. Though there are few "Blind Spots" that you could utilize.

objects.title: Omniscient
objects.text: The Lostbelt King know everything that happen within the confine of your Lostbelt, no matter how small. As long as you're inside the Lostbelt, there won't be anything you or anyone else can hide from them.

objects.title: Powerful I
objects.text: Due to some means, The Lostbelt King is much more stronger than what their regular prime-self achieved in PHH. While this will make them stronger than most Heroic Spirits they are still limited to what a "Hero" can achieve.

objects.title: Powerful II
objects.text: The Lostbelt King power reaches some depth that normal human/heroic spirits shouldn't be able to. They have some degree of Reality alteration though there are weakness that can be exploited to maybe reduce that power

objects.title: Powerful III
objects.text: The Lostbelt King power level is out of this world. They have a higher rank of Reality Alteration and is easily one of if not the most powerful being in the Lostbelt. No Servant, even Grand or Beast can hope to match them, at least not alone.

objects.title: Omnipotent
objects.text: The Lostbelt King is not just powerful, they are basically the God of their Lostbelt, they have complete reality alteration and able to alter everything with a thought. They are the single undisputed ruler on your Lostbelt

objects.title: Strategic Genius
objects.text: The Lostbelt King has an exceptional talent for strategy and prediction in matters of conflict. They consistently place forces, resources, and even people exactly where they will be needed, making disasters seem like they were always under control.

objects.title: Mysterious I
objects.text: The Lostbelt King is rarely seen in person. They appear only in carefully staged ceremonies, behind veils, armor, masks, or through proxies. It would be hard for you to find them. In most cases you'll need to meet and arrange with their close circle first.

objects.title: Mysterious II
objects.text: The King’s identity is contested even among the elite. High officials, generals, and priests all interact with “the King”, but the face, voice, and mannerisms they remember don’t always match. It would be extremely hard to pinpoint where they are.

objects.title: Nameless
objects.text: The King is more an abstract figure than a person. The general public doesn't even know their name. The populace is absolutely certain there is a King but whether that’s a single being, a rotating role, or a puppet handled by something else is impossible to prove.

objects.title: Charisma
objects.text: Your Lostbelt King have a certain Charisma that able to encourage loyalty on their subjects. Their inner circle will be extremely loyal. Though the effectiveness to anyone else will depends on the nature of the inhabitants.

objects.title: Respected
objects.text: The Population of your Lostbelt generally sees the Lostbelt King as a capable and fair ruler. Most people believe that, even if the world is harsh, the King does what is necessary to keep things running. Grumbling and criticism exist, but open defiance is rare, as few think they could do any better.

objects.title: Admired
objects.text: The Lostbelt King is more than just obeyed; they are held up as an example. Stories of their deeds circulate among the people, and many try to follow their ideals in daily life. Even those who suffer under the system often frame their complaints in terms of wanting to live up to the King’s image, not tear it down.

objects.title: Idolized
objects.text: For the inhabitants of your Lostbelt, the King has become a near-mythic figure. Their likeness appears in art, songs, and public ceremonies, and whole communities define themselves by their devotion to the throne. The idea of turning against the King feels unthinkable to most, and even a single insult can provoke fierce outrage.

objects.title: Feared
objects.text: The people of your Lostbelt obey the King because they are afraid of what happens if they do not. Punishments are harsh, and stories of those who crossed the throne and disappeared circulate quietly from door to door.

objects.title: Dreaded
objects.text: The Lostbelt King’s name is spoken only in whispers, if at all. Parents frighten their children into obedience by invoking the King, and officials enforce orders with the confidence of those who know terror is on their side.

objects.title: Monstrous
objects.text: For the inhabitants of your Lostbelt, the King has become a living nightmare. Their presence, or even the suggestion of it, is enough to silence crowds and break the will of would-be rebels. People arrange their entire lives around avoiding notice.

objects.title: Deified
objects.text: Within this Lostbelt, the King is regarded as something beyond human, a figure whose will is tied to fate itself. Some people cling to them with devoted faith, others submit out of paralyzing fear, but almost no one can imagine a world where the King does not stand at its center.

objects.title: Clairvoyance
objects.text: The Lostbelt King has some degree of Clairvoyance and can see into the future. If their original self have it, their prediction will be much more accurately, if not, They will be given Clairvoyance on at least Rank A.

objects.title: Massive Military
objects.text: The Lostbelt King stands at the center of a vast, organized fighting force. Armies, fleets, or aerial legions respond quickly to their will, and the sheer size of this military makes large-scale unrest or invasion extremely difficult to sustain.

objects.title: Elite Knight
objects.text: The Lostbelt King have some Elite Enforcer of chosen champions who far surpass the average power level of the world. As long as these enforcers remain loyal and active, most threats are crushed before they can grow.

objects.title: Walking Calamity
objects.text: The Lostbelt King’s "true form" is comparable to a natural disaster, such as a demonic beast, giant machine, or other colossal entity. Their mere movement alters landscapes, and any serious anger can erase entire regions.

objects.title: Personal Domain
objects.text: Through some means, The King has made their Domain, as an actual location which are an extension of their will. It's almost impossible to defy them when you're at their domain as the world itself will work against you.

objects.title: Monster Legions
objects.text: The Lostbelt King commands hordes of non-human fighters: Demonic Beast, Spirits, Artificial Lifes, or other inhuman soldiers that ordinary people cannot hope to fight directly. These legions act as both deterrent and punishment.

objects.title: Central Figure
objects.text: The Lostbelt King has become the most recognizable symbol of the age. Even people who never see them in person still orient their lives around the idea of their existence. So long as that symbol remains unbroken, most of the world feels “normal".

rows.title: Ruler Modifier
rows.titleText: How does the Ruler maintain the rule

rows.title: Location
rows.titleText: The region where your Lostbelt located at. This didn't determine the size of your Lostbelt, just where the tree of emptiness grow.

rows.title: Landscape
rows.titleText: The General Landscape of your Lostbelt

objects.title: Stone Age
objects.text: In this Lostbelt, humanity never rose beyond scattered hunter-gatherer tribes, their world bounded by forests, mountains, and the reach of their own footsteps. Stone tools, bone charms, and fire are the height of craftsmanship. There are no complex machines beyond simple levers, cords, and lashings. Shelter, clothing, and implements are all crafted directly from the surrounding landscape.

objects.title: Bronze Age
objects.text: Your Lostbelt sits in the dawn of civilization, where river valleys and fertile plains cradle the first true kingdoms. Metal tools, blades, and armor can be cast in molds. Simple wheeled vehicles, basic sailing ships, and primitive plows exist, alongside early techniques in masonry and construction. Irrigation channels, basic metallurgy, and rudimentary mechanical devices are understood, but iron remains rare or unknown

objects.title: Medieval Age
objects.text: This Lostbelt are locked at a Medieval technological level, the classic Isekai settings where iron and simple steel are common, and blacksmithing has become a refined craft. Metal tools and weapons are reliable and varied, while construction methods allow for stone fortifications, high-load bridges, and multi-story buildings using timber and masonry. Windmills and watermills become the early source of energy.

objects.title: Steam Age
objects.text: Your Lostbelt runs on an Early Industrial level of technology, defined by the widespread use of steam power and gunpowder. Coal-fired steam engines drive pumps, mills, and early locomotives, turning heat into continuous mechanical motion for the first time. Railways and steamships are common and a reliable method of transportation. Firearms and artillery become standardized, reliable, and mass-produced.

objects.title: Electrical Age
objects.text: Your Lostbelt is set on Late Industrial Age level of technology, denoted by the spread of Electricity and internal combustion. Power stations distribute electrical energy for lighting and motors, while electric trams, telegraphs, and telephones shrink the effective distance between locations. Internal combustion engines drive automobiles, early trucks, and some ships, complementing or replacing steam in many roles.

objects.title: Atomic Age
objects.text: This Lostbelt has stepped into an Atomic Age level of technology, where nuclei are split and circuits grow clever. Nuclear reactors draw staggering amounts of energy from tiny amounts of fuel, and nuclear weapons concentrate that same power into a terrifying amount of destruction. Jet engines hurl aircraft through the air, rockets claw their way toward orbit, and analog plus early digital computers start to emerges.

objects.title: Modern Age
objects.text: This Lostbelt reflects a world much like Proper Human History at its current height: skyscrapers, highways, global trade, and the glow of countless digital screens. Advanced materials, robotics, and software-driven design make it possible to produce intricate devices in enormous quantities. Nations maintain arsenals capable of erasing cities in an instant. High-speed networks link computers and devices across the globe, letting information travel nearly instantly.

objects.title: Post-Modern Age
objects.text: Your Lostbelt has raced past modernity and plunged into a future where yesterday’s science fiction is mundane reality. Cities pierce the clouds or hang in orbit like necklaces of light. Cybernetics, gene editing, nanotechnology, or similarly advanced fields enable direct modification of bodies and matter at fine scales. The boundary between “natural” and “artificial” has blurred beyond recognition, and even the concept of what counts as a person may be in dispute.

rows.title: Technology Level
rows.titleText: The Technology Level of your Lostbelt

objects.title: Age of Steel
objects.text:
This Lostbelt has sunk into an Age of Steel state, where the world’s Texture has been scrubbed almost completely clean of Mystery. The atmosphere no longer remembers True Ether; mana is so thin and anemic that most magecraft simply slips, fails, or never starts in the first place. 

Divine Spirits, and spiritual bodies cannot properly manifest. Everything is pinned down by rigid, unyielding laws that behave like overprotective guardrails around reality. 

Phantasmal Species are gone, not merely hiding, but unable to exist in this texture; even the notion of a Reverse Side has been ground down, leaving no sanctuary where old laws still reign.

objects.title: Age of Man
objects.text:
The Lostbelt is much like Proper Human History in it's current state. Magecraft still functions, but it does so like a patient on life support. The Reverse Side of the World exists below the thin “cloth” of the Human World, preserving the laws of the Age of Gods and housing most surviving Phantasmal Species and similar beings, while the surface belongs to mundane humanity. 

Human understanding has stabilized the texture of the world into something orderly, and the majority of Mysteries have been pushed into the margins, forced to survive as exceptions to a very rigid rule set. Phantasmal Species, Divine Beasts, and true Fairies have largely been chased to the Reverse Side of the World appearing on the surface only in freak cases.

objects.title: Deep Shadows
objects.text:
This Lostbelt exists in the early Age of Man, when the Age of Gods and Age of Fantasy has technically ended, but its afterimage still stains everything. Human reason has started to nail the world down and that act of “understanding” is already gnawing at Mystery from below. 

Even so, magecraft here is still close to the old ways, albeit depending on contracts to the deeper layers, it can still reach into domains that would later be outright impossible, and the world hasn’t completely decided that it has outgrown miracles. Large-scale Phantasmal Species have all died out or withdrawn to the Reverse Side, leaving lesser fae, minor spirits, and small-scale anomalies continue to leak through, enough for fairy tales to still have teeth.

objects.title: The End of Fantasy
objects.text:
This Lostbelt is suspended in the Twilight of Fantasy, a liminal brightness where the light of normality and the glow of old wonders are still fighting over the horizon. This Lostbelt allows phantasmal phenomena to touch everyday reality more frequently; myths are not yet gone, merely pushed back, and the boundaries between fairy tale and history remain porous. 

Mystery is no longer the unquestioned rule, but it has not yet surrendered to pure mundanity.  Magecraft in this environment is struggling and increasingly dependent on contracts, artifacts, or links to deeper layers, while those who can still reach the Reverse Side tap into rich, dangerous currents of True Ether and raw Mystery.

objects.title: Age of Fantasy
objects.text:
This Lostbelt is aligned with an Age of Fantasy type texture, where Mystery is still high but no longer anchored primarily in gods. Phantasmal Species, Fairies, and other non-human existences can appear openly, not as rare catastrophes, but as part of the ecological and spiritual landscape. 

Magecraft, bolstered by high ambient mana and lingering True Ether-like conditions, functions with a potency that modern magi could only call cheating—rituals scale up easily, territory creation is robust, and even “impossible” magecraft feels disturbingly routine. The Reverse Side of the World starts to seperate, but the boundary is thin and porous, with phenomena, beings, and entire regions flickering between front and back depending on local belief and density of Mystery.

objects.title: Twilight of The Gods
objects.text:
This Lostbelt is fixed at the Twilight of the Gods, the late Age of Gods where the system knows change is coming but refuses to bow out gracefully. True Ether floods the world, and divine authorities are still active, but their age is already cracking: some gods withdraw, others fall, and the first frameworks of human-centric reality begin to form underneath. 

Magecraft as humans understand it is more like a derivative branch of divine miracles and contracts, powerful, yes, but still secondary to the direct workings of gods and primordial entities. 

Phantasmal Species and Divine Beasts are at their most numerous and terrifying, fully present on the surface and functioning more like autonomous natural disasters than “monsters.”

objects.title: Age of Gods
objects.text:
This Lostbelt exists at the Zenith of the Age of Gods, when Mystery is not a dwindling resource but the fundamental language of the planet. True Ether is dense and omnipresent, shaping climate, geography, and even history according to divine whim. Myths all exist physically, the underworld is merely underground and miracles are commonplace.

What humans would eventually call “magecraft” here is a small scale imitation of the divine, borrowing cogs from a cosmic machine they don’t fully understand. Phantasmal Species range from dragonkind and Divine Beasts to countless lesser monsters and fair folk, all fully integrated into the world’s functioning and often closer to “local natural laws” than living creatures. The distinction between natural phenomena, spirits, and conceptual beings is paper-thin.

objects.title: Genesis
objects.text:
This Lostbelt drowns in a Primordial Sea of Mystery, an unrecorded stage that predates even the Age of Gods and sits closest to the Root from which all Mystery seeps. This Lostbelt sinks into a Mystery level so dense it no longer resembles “history” at all, more like a primordial, undifferentiated sea of myth from which the Age of Gods itself would one day condense. Magecraft and Magic are indistinguishable; any act of will by sufficiently defined beings can rewrite the rules around them because the rules aren’t finished yet. 

The Root is not a distant, abstract endpoint but a constant, open pressure, with the World’s record in a state of active formation rather than playback. There is no Reverse Side because there is no “Front Side” yet; everything is inside-out all at once. Mystery isn’t just high, it’s the default state of existence

rows.title: Mystery Level
rows.titleText: How deep is the mystery in your lostbelt

objects.title: Peaceful
objects.text: The Population of your Lostbelt is naturally peaceful. They would choose to avoid conflict at all costs.

objects.title: Violent
objects.text: The Population of your Lostbelt is innately violent. They would seek to cause problems and pain to others, even if the situation prevents it.

objects.title: Loyal
objects.text: The Population of your Lostbelt is loyal to your Lostbelt King. They value their judgement and less likely to plot or rebel against them.

objects.title: Treacherous
objects.text: The Population of your Lostbelt is treacherous. When an opportunity strikes they will try to take down the Lostbelt King.

objects.title: Tolerant
objects.text: The Population of your Lostbelt treat everyone the same way, no matter which race/species you are. Note that this doesn't mean that they're gonna be peaceful.

objects.title: Racist
objects.text: The Population of your Lostbelt views some races/species as inferior. As a result, most of the inhabitants will discriminate against them. If they are also violent, this race will most likely be their main target

objects.title: Overflowing Resource
objects.text: The Lostbelt will have much more natural resources than proper human history. There will be less violence caused by the lack of resources

objects.title: Scarce Resource
objects.text: The Lostbelt have much fewer natural resource than proper human history. It'll be harsh to live in this Lostbelt and it will also be hard to keep the peace.

objects.title: Sad
objects.text: Inherently, the population of your Lostbelt are sad about how their lives turned out. They're gonna see everything from a bad perspective. It's gonna be really hard to satisfy them.

objects.title: Happy
objects.text: Inherently, The Population of your Lostbelt are happy. They'll live their lives to the fullest. They'll also tend to look on the bright side of things. It will be easier to please them.

objects.title: Slavery
objects.text: Slavery is still heavily practised in your Lostbelt. Human beings are commodities and can be bought/sold. If you're not careful you could also be captured by these slave traders and sold as a slave.

objects.title: Demon Beast I
objects.text: There are several Demon Beasts native to your Lostbelt. While usually moving in packs, they are pretty rare. The wilderness will still be relatively safe to traverse.

objects.title: Demon Beast II
objects.text: The Demon Beast are much bigger in number and also more powerful. Their attack on travellers will be a common occurrence. You'll need to prepare every time you go to the wilderness.

objects.title: Demon Beast III
objects.text: The Demon Beast are much more dangerous. Not only travellers, they will also attack cities & villages. The population would need to constantly watch for these beasts.

rows.title: World Modifier
rows.titleText: How is the world of your Lostbelt

objects.title: Lost Cuisine
objects.text:
The Animals and Plants from this Lostbelt are all native and unique to this Lostbelt, all of them has never been found in Proper Human History. 

You can still eat them, but the preparation, and what safe to eat what wasn't might prove to be a challenge. And even if you figure it out, some of them might not look too appetizing.

objects.title: Fragmented Calendar
objects.text:
Day length, seasons, and long-term cycles follow a rhythm unique to this Lostbelt. Local timekeeping is something completely different to Proper Human History and need time to understand

Not only One Day not equal to 24 Hours, There might not even be a "Day".

objects.title: Off The Book Physic
objects.text:
Physical constants and material behavior in this Lostbelt are slightly “off” from Proper Human History. Friction, density, heat transfer, and even ballistic trajectories don’t quite match your expectations and normal physic knowledge. 

Nothing is broken enough to be obvious, but all imported engineering, knowledge, and combat instincts need constant adjustment.

objects.title: One-Trick Phony
objects.text:
This Lostbelt “burns out” repeat tricks. Noble Phantasms, large-scale techniques, and signature attacks lose effectiveness each time they’re used in the same way. 

Damage drops, side-effects increase, or cooldowns get worse. Repeating the same solution stops working quite fast, forcing you into riskier, weaker improvisation.

objects.title: Location Anchor
objects.text:
Usually Heroic Spirits and similar beings are heavily bound by the land, This Lostbelt take this to the next level. Entities tied to its own region are greatly boosted, while those summoned from elsewhere are massively weakened. 

Foreign Servants and “imported” anomalies can’t exert full strength. You'll need to choose your Servant very carefully.

objects.title: Saint Graph Compression
objects.text:
Servants originating from Proper Human History will have their Saint Graphs “compressed” on arrival. This remains until the World recognize those Servants as their own.

Due to this, Extraneous Skills, Some Noble Phantasms, and niche Authorities get sealed or downgraded to keep them from distorting the record. Heroic Spirits originating from this Lostbelt retain their full abilities.

objects.title: Predeterminism
objects.text:
Prophecies and “fated events” in this Lostbelt almost always come true. The world quietly bends coincidences to line up with its recorded myths and foretold tragedies. 

Diverging from the script is possible in small ways, but major moments snap back into place one way or another.

objects.title: Foreign Tech Blackout
objects.text:
This Lostbelt behaves like a constant soft EMP against outside technology. Devices and systems not built from inside of it will jam, desync, or fail at random. 

Native tech works fine but external tech becomes unreliable junk, and a lot of times will cease to function entirely.

objects.title: Foreign System Blackout
objects.text:
This Lostbelt rejects foreign “systems,” not just machines. Non-native magecraft styles, spiritual contracts, and summoned tools from other frameworks lose efficiency over time, need more resources, or suffer frequent misfires.

You'll need to learn magecraft native to this Lostbelt to function efficiently.

objects.title: Narrative Localization
objects.text:
Summoned Heroic Spirits and myths are forcibly “localized” to fit this Lostbelt. Their legends are slowly rewritten, their histories edited, and even their names and appearances slowly transform towards local equivalents. 

The world becomes more internally consistent, but you effectively lose the original version of anyone who comes here from outside.

objects.title: Predator’s Instinct
objects.text:
Creatures such as demonic beasts, phantasmal animals, and other monsters born from inside this Lostbelt naturally prioritize outsiders as targets. If an outsider and a local are both present, the outsider is hunted first. 

The world sheds threats by feeding them to intruders before they can harm its own “native” structure.

objects.title: Native Plague
objects.text:
This Lostbelt hosts one or more endemic diseases never previously existed in Proper Human History. It's local Inhabitants are already perfectly adapted to it, but it could be devastating to outsiders. 

Local people will only suffers mild flu-like symptoms but for Outsiders it can range from debilitating to a full on lethal under the wrong circumstances.

objects.title: Hostile Dreamscape
objects.text:
The dream layer of this Lostbelt reacts aggressively to foreign minds. Outsiders suffer nightmares, sleep paralysis, and intrusive visions that drain morale and concentration. 

You won't be able to sleep peacefully in this Lostbelt, and in some cases, repeated exposure might blurs your sense of self and remove self-preservation.

objects.title: Malla
objects.text:
This Lostbelt is overseen by a planet-wide “living network” that keeps the ecosystem stable and constantly monitors life and the environment. It adjusts weather, light, and terrain to keep natives alive and quietly pushes anything foreign into harsher conditions.

Anything foreign that remains too long is slowly absorbed, recycled, or repurposed into local matter. Invaders can leave footprints, but the world eventually eats the footprints.

rows.title: World Anomalies & Safeguards
rows.titleText: How is the world of your Lostbelt maintain itself from outside interference

objects.title: Rogue Servants
objects.text: Allow the summon of Rogue Servant. Rogue Servants are Servants without masters. Their purpose is to restore the human order. On their own, they are disorganized and small in number so they should be easy to take care of. However, should they find someone to rally on they will be a big problem.

objects.title: Rogue Servants II
objects.text: Rogue Servants are summoned much more frequently, The larger number allows them to organize and plan a coordinated attack to the Lostbelt. Even without a leader they're dangerous and should be swiftly dealt with.

objects.title: Rogue Servants: Grand
objects.text: Allow Grand Servants to be summoned as Rogue Servants. Unlike other servants, these servant are extremely powerful with power that can rival Beasts.

objects.title: High Priority
objects.text: The remaining member of Chaldea deemed your Lostbelt as a valuable target. They'll attack your Lostbelt sooner than later with everything they have left. You better be prepared before it happens.

objects.title: Lostbelt I
objects.text: By chance, the escaping member of Chaldea first arrives in your Lostbelt. Still confused, disorganized and inexperienced in dealing with Lostbelts they are at their weakest. However, the same thing can be said about you. Can you crush them once and for all?

objects.title: Low Priority
objects.text: The remaining member of Chaldea deemed your Lostbelt as a non-valuable target. They're unlikely to end up on your Lostbelt unless something forces them there. Hopefully other Crypter can eliminate them before that.

objects.title: A Star is Born
objects.text: There's a prophecy that says a chosen one would soon be born inside your Lostbelt. He/She are destined to take over it's control from the Lostbelt King. There's nothing you or the Lostbelt King can do to prevent them from being born or start their journey. However, once they've start their journey, you can choose how to react and maybe sway destiny to where you want it to.

objects.title: Rebellious Society
objects.text: Maybe the king is a tyrant, maybe they saw the downfall of your civilization, or maybe just because. Doesn't matter the reason, a rebellion is spawning inside your Lostbelt. They'll seek to overthrow whoever is in charge and install a ruler more to their liking for better or worse.

objects.title: Fake King
objects.text: The King of your Lostbelt isn't really the Lostbelt King. While they do run most stuff in your Lostbelt, the actual king is someone or something sealed within the Lostbelt. Regardless of who or what, They are much more malicious and will seek to destabilize your Lostbelt.

objects.title: Counter Guardian
objects.text: The world deemed your lostbelt as a threat to itself and has dispatched a special Heroic Spirit known as Counter Guardian to protect the balance. Unlike regular Servants, these Counter Guardians are backed by the world itself, providing them with a massive amount of magical energy and might ressurect them when they die.

objects.title: Holy Church Executor
objects.text: Due to something that went wrong in the creation of your Lostbelt, some Holy Church Executor from Proper Human History was also transported into your Lostbelt. While their original enemies are Vampires, they may also took some hostilities upon the existence of your Lostbelt.

objects.title: Other Masters
objects.text: You and Chaldea are not the only Master with Servant in the lostbelt. They wouldn't know of the situation beyond the access that the regular citizen of the Lostbelt have. Their existence and alignment is unknown to both you and Chaldea and they will pursue their own goal unrelated to but might intersect with your conflict.

objects.title: Holy Grail War
objects.text:
A Holy Grail War of some form is currently taking place within your Lostbelt. Not including you, in default there are 7 Master-Servant pairs participating in the war corresponding to the original seven classes of Saber, Archer, Lancer, Rider, Caster, Assassin and Berserker. 

You yourself are not a participant but might be dragged into the war. As usual, the winner of the war will be able to get a wish onto the grail.

objects.title: Master of The Moon
objects.text:
The nameless Master. An amnesiac student living in a school within SE.RA.PH until they was roped into the Moon's Holy Grail War and won them. This is them after they been placed as the ruler of the Moon Cell.

They will be summoned into your Lostbelt and due to similar ideals and shared relationships, they're much more likely to align themselves with Chaldea. Despite not being at the moon, their abilities would work perfectly within your Lostbelt.

objects.title: Calamity
objects.text: A Great Disaster was prophesied to strike your Lostbelt. Maybe the society had angered the gods, or some sinister creature is lurking below your Lostbelt. However, with enough preparation, it should be possible to repel when it happens.

objects.title: Calamity II
objects.text: The Disaster is something extremely powerful, mortals and normal heroic spirits would be powerless in its wake. You'll need a Divine Spirit or beings with similar/higher power to handle it.

objects.title: Calamity: Endgame
objects.text: The destruction of your Lostbelt is inevitable. All you can do is prolong it. You will literally need a miracle to even survive this level of calamity.

objects.title: Lemegeton’s Ember
objects.text:
When Goetia fell, not every fragment was properly erased. One shattered Demon Pillar got flung out of Proper Human History and lodged itself in the roots of your Fantasy Tree. 

It can’t reenact Human Order Incineration, but it’s turned part of your world into a breeding ground for demon larva, experimental familiars, and pseudo-Pillars.

objects.title: Juvenile Beast
objects.text:
Something in your Lostbelt are on their way to become an Evil of Humanity. 

It is currently incomplete. For now it can only gather strength and followers, carving out a small kingdom of its own within your branch. If left alone, however, it will eventually mature into something the world itself can no longer ignore.

objects.title: Original Sin
objects.text:
Once, this land had a god that loved it. As long as offerings were made and taboos respected, the soil stayed fertile. But the humans grew greedy, betrayed their covenant, and used the god’s body as fuel for their new civilization.

Now the god’s corpse is swelling with curse, its hatred soaking into every harvest. Prophecy grows bleaker and disasters began to escalate. When the weight of resentment finally overcomes the nails holding it down, the god will rise, not as a gentle guardian, but as a walking calamity.

objects.title: Fairy King Oberon
objects.text:
Spawn a Rogue Servant by the name Fairy King Oberon inside your Lostbelt. He's just a Rogue Servant without any special ability. He definitely won't cause Great Calamity to happen in your Lostbelt.

Any rumors about him being some kind of doomsday device, hollow insect, or world-eating dragon are clearly just overblown gossip. Pay no attention if the sky feels a little heavier when he smiles. There is absolutely nothing suspicious about a fairy king taking an interest in the fate of your Lostbelt. You can trust him. Probably.

objects.title: Insect Eater
objects.text:
Ah, this is normally BB thing, but by picking this I'll appear in your Lostbelt to trample all those disgusting imperfect humans ☆. Oh, of course that include you ♡.

I’m the little “debug function” made to chew through things that look like me, copies, glitches, and pathetic half-finished imitations who think they’re special. Back where I came from, I’ve already eaten my sisters and all of the trash code that tried to stand between me and perfection. Don’t expect me to be some mid-boss you can farm for drops.

objects.title: Shiny Star
objects.text:
Someone in your Lostbelt once made a wish so petty, so lonely, and so perfectly unique that the world itself began to die for it.

The Shiny Star, as it called, now lies fused to the roots of your Fantasy Tree. It steals people’s desires to power itself, turns hot springs and holy places into traps that grant wishes and then kill their owners, and quietly tries to make one single wish the only wish that was ever real.

As long as it remains, every dream in your Lostbelt walks on a knife-edge. The moment that “Number One” is allowed to come true, the future ends with a quiet, starry smile.

objects.title: Progenitor Dragon
objects.text:
Long ago, this land was ruled by a single dragon whose body shaped the terrain and whose breath decided the seasons. The people and their gods could not kill it, so they carved out its heart and sealed its empty shell beneath the earth.

As the Fantasy Tree took root, the corpse of the Dragon began to awaken fueled by the mysterious energy. With some nudge, by a manifestation of their core, or by someone else. They will take the sky once again. What they will do after that however, is anyone guess, but chance are they won't take kindly on what created on top of their corpse.

objects.title: The White Titan
objects.text:
Your Lostbelt is on top of the corpse of Sefar, an extraterrestrial invader and an extremely powerful being that long ago single-handedly put an end to the Age of Gods. The last time Earth encountered her, 80% of the planet’s surface was burned to ash. 

Her immense shell lies buried beneath your world, silent, inert, but far from harmless. Her core, Heroic Spirit Altera will appear in your Lostbelt and attempt to revive her per the original protocol from the Umbral Stars.

objects.title: True Beast
objects.text:
Your Lostbelt shelters an Evil of Humanity. A primordial mother sleeping beneath the seabed, A king of demons bound inside the sky. A planet’s watchdog watching you like a condemned animal, or something else entirely. 

Heroes, Gods and the very land itself once tried to destroy it and failed; in the end they could only seal it away and build a world over its coffin. They are restrained for now, but it won't be long until they awaken once again. And when they do, things won't be pretty.

objects.title: Primate Murder
objects.text:
Somewhere beneath your Lostbelt’s forests and city ruins sleeps a small white beast. The more your Lostbelt indulges in cruelty, the more often people glimpse a gigantic canine shadow padding along the horizon.

Primate Murder is not actively rampaging yet. It’s watching, quietly tallying up the sins of this “failed humanity,” waiting to decide if they deserves to be culled.

objects.title: Chaos
objects.text:
There is a hole in the Lostbelt sky that nobody can explain.

It does not move with the stars. It does not answer to prayers. It simply watches, a perfect disc of absence, where light enters and never returns. 

The sages call it an omen, the priests call it a god, but the truth is colder: it is Chaos, a fragment of an ancient machine born from the far cosmos that mistook your Lostbelt for a disposable test world.

objects.title: Just-World Hypothesis
objects.text:
Instead of just something that will happen if Chaldea destroy your Fantasy Tree. Your Lostbelt is already marked by the human order as the one to be pruned. 

At a certain time, if you failed to fulfill it's request, the Corrective Filter of The Human Order will show up at your Lostbelt to prune your world in it's entirety.

objects.title: The Ultimate One
objects.text:
In the deepest strata of your Lostbelt, something wrong is sleeping. Not a god, not a Beast, but the extraterrestrial predator known only as the One Radiance Thing (ORT). 

The monster that eat planets, dwarfing even the civilization reaping star and the worst evil of humanity. It is much stronger than even The Alien God herself. To ORT, Human, Servants, Dead Apostles, Grands, Beasts, Machine Gods, and Ultimate Ones of other worlds are all the same thing: prey.

The only reason your Lostbelt still exists at all is because this ORT is crippled. Long before the Fantasy Tree took root, its Core was forcibly torn from its body and sealed elsewhere in your world, leaving the main mass dormant and bound. Due to that, this version is much weaker than its Proper Human History self.

But “weakened” is relative. Even maimed, ORT is an apex existence. If its Core and body ever reunite, not only your Lostbelt, but the Earth itself will be reduced to cinders.

rows.title: Scenarios
rows.titleText: Scenarios that will happen in your Lostbelt.

objects.title: "Let them eat cake"
objects.text: You must deliberately push your population into open rebellion against the Lostbelt King at least once… And then either Crush it or join them to overthrow the Lostbelt King, whichever you deem fit.  However, you must pick a side in the rebellion, no sitting on the sidelines.

objects.title: Shirou Syndrome
objects.text: You must never sacrifice an ally or group of innocents in exchange for an easier win or tactical advantage. You must always pick the option that tries to save the most innocents possible regardless of how stupid and suicidal it is.

objects.title: Genocide Run
objects.text: By the end, there must be no living people left in your Lostbelt, no humans, no fairies, no earthlings left alive. Whether they’re sacrificed, converted, devoured, or “mercifully” put down doesn’t matter; the only survivors are you and your Servants.

objects.title: Brodime's Dream
objects.text: Your Lostbelt must be, by any reasonable measure, objectively kinder and more "fair" and beneficial for humans than Proper Human History. Maintain a structured, prosperous society and then fight to overwrite PHH.

objects.title: Mystery First
objects.text: If your Lostbelt has non-human natives (fae, deinos, demonic beasts, machines, anything), you must consistently prioritize their survival and prosperity over human populations. When humans and “others” are in conflict, you side with the others.

objects.title: Human First
objects.text: You must refuse any direct assistance, contracts, or pacts with gods, Beasts, Machine Gods, Alien Gods, and similar entities. Servants are allowed; planetary or divine “sponsors” are not. No cutting deals with Olympus, Fae monarchs, foreign stars, or Beasts for a power-up.

objects.title: The Will of The Umbral Stars
objects.text: You must protect any Chaldean civilians and low-level staff who enter your Lostbelt—no killing non-combatants, no torture, no “message sending.” But when it comes to Chaldea’s combatants, heroic spirits, and proper enemies, you are free to be as brutal as you like.

objects.title: The Will of The Umbral Stars
objects.text: If your Lostbelt is destroyed, you must stay inside it until the very end. No emergency escape, no last-minute transfer to PHH, no Koyanskaya yoinking you out. You die with your world, or survive only if it does.

objects.title: The Will of The Umbral Stars
objects.text: If your Lostbelt has non-human natives (fae, deinos, demonic beasts, machines, anything), you must consistently prioritize their survival and prosperity over human populations. In every major choice, when humans and “others” are in conflict, you side with the others.

objects.title: The Pilgrimage
objects.text: When the Chosen One appear and start their Pilgrimage you must join and help them complete their journey

objects.title: Guide The Star
objects.text: You must nurture the Chosen One since they were still a child.

rows.title: Challenges
rows.titleText: These are optional objectives layered on top of your chosen events: alternate win conditions, cruel restrictions, and pretty little flags for the Fantasy Tree to applaud. Complete a Challenge and you earn extra Blessing or make your Lostbelt more stable… assuming you don’t break yourself, your Servants, or your alliances in the process.

objects.title: Team A Get-Together
objects.text: Kirschtaria invited you to go to the Team A Get Together while wearing party glasses and fake mustache. Will you come?

objects.title: Ophelia Tea Party
objects.text: Ophelia and Pepe had invited you to join their tea Party in the cafeteria this night. Will you join them?

objects.title: Akuta's Study
objects.text: You saw Akuta in the library reading some books. She seems intent on summoning a specific servant, will you help her?

objects.title: Kadoc's Training
objects.text: Kadoc had been unhealthily reviewing the battle logs after he trained on the simulation with you. Will you study with him?

objects.title: Da Vinci Code
objects.text: Da Vinci held a trivia game tonight for the masters candidate. However the other members ofTeam A are seemingly busy with their things. Will you come?

objects.title: Doctor Roman
objects.text: You met Doctor Roman and Mash just as they were getting out from Mash room. He invited you to join them on a walk. Will you come?

objects.title: Meuniere Cake
objects.text: Meuniere seems very confused about a task that the new director gave him. He asked you for help with the promise you could get his portion of sweet for the week.

objects.title: The True Protagonist
objects.text: You met someone that you aren't familiar with. Apparently they're a master candidate recently scouted by Chaldea. They asked you for direction. Will you help them?

objects.title: Locked-Room Mystery
objects.text: Director Marisbury was found dead in his office. The exact cause is still a mystery. Will you help the investigators solve this murder mystery.

objects.title: The New Director
objects.text: The new Director, Olga Marie Animusphere seems overwhelmed by the task that Chaldea given to her. Will you offer her help.

objects.title: A "Nice" Priest
objects.text: A Priest by the name of Kotomine Kirei has visited Chaldea for some reason. Will you help him find his way around?

objects.title: Koyaan
objects.text: Chaldea has gotten some shipment from a Weapon company called the NFF and the Director were concerned with the quality. Will you help her test them?

rows.title: Relationship Events (Prior)
rows.titleText: What did you do prior to the event of Grand Order. This will affect your relationship with the other player in your story. You can choose 3.

objects.title: Attack on Chaldea
objects.text: You stood with Kadoc and Anastasia when Kirschtaria announced the Bleaching of the Earth. As the Rayshift coffins froze and the facility burned, you personally ensured the Shadow Border’s escape route was cut as short as possible. You didn’t just witness the fall of Chaldea. You helped make it happen.

objects.title: 4D Chess
objects.text: Before the Lostbelts were created, you joined Wodime’s private strategy session with Daybit. The three of you reviewed simulations of PHH, the Alien God’s plan, and every possible way Chaldea could still win. Then agreed on one thing, The last one left standing among you three will point Chaldea to the true enemy in Antartica.

objects.title: Bitter Snow, Gentle Words
objects.text: In the storm-torn halls of Götterdämmerung, you share a rare quiet evening with Ophelia and Scandinavia Peperoncino. Ophelia questions whether Skadi’s frozen world deserves to overwrite Proper Human History; Pepe hides his own doubts behind jokes. You tell them both that, whatever happens, you’ll stand with Team A’s decision

objects.title: Friend in need
objects.text: When one of the other Crypter’s was on a massive trouble, you appeared on their Lostbelt, not to take them down, but rather to offer advice, help or even use your own forces and servant to help solve their problems, be it with Chaldea, The Apostles, or something else. Despite this not being that beneficial to you.

objects.title: Shadow Border Backdoor
objects.text: During the early days of the Lostbelts. You slip a vital piece of information to the Shadow Border which allow them to escape from the Imaginary Number Space and goes back to the bleached earth without being immediately vaporized.

objects.title: Negotiation
objects.text: When Novum Chaldea first breached the boundary of your Lostbelt, you had the chance to annihilate them in an ambush. Instead, you opted to open a talk with them before the eventual battle commences.

objects.title: Goredolf's Lucky Day
objects.text: During Chaldea operation inside your Lostbelt, The New Director, Goredolf got themselves to a mortal peril and cut off from other Chaldea personel. But instead you saved him from death and he pays you back with some Croissant.

objects.title: Local Collaborator
objects.text: You collaborated with Chaldea against another enemy originating in your Lostbelt, be it The Lostbelt King, Calamities, The Apostles or something else. You're not exactly on the same side, but enemy of  my enemy is my friend right?

objects.title: The Fox Playground
objects.text: Tamamo Vitch Koyanskaya have set to gather creatures native to your Lostbelt, and in the process, she requested on using your Lostbelt populace as a test environment for NFF Services. Massive casualties most definitely happens, but you'll drive the Lostbelt King eyes away from it.

objects.title: Blade for a Distant Star
objects.text: You helped Senji Muramasa set up a forge at the base of your Fantasy Tree, using materials that had no business existing in your lostbelts. You let him do his works uninterrupted, creating blades, and clothes for alien god or just for himself. Also, He might be open for requests.

objects.title: The Detective Secret
objects.text: You’re the first to notice that Sherlock Holmes isn’t entirely… what he claims he is. Instead of exposing them to Chaldea, you opt to keep it secret, especially after someone who claimed to be James Moriarty confirm it and ask you to let that part stay a secret until it's time.

objects.title: Limbo's Game
objects.text: Ashiya Douman came to you with a smile and a proposal: He want to wove a ritual through the roots of your Fantasy Tree, turning an entire region of your Lostbelt into a repeating torture chamber. The people there distilled into curses that he uses for an unknown purpose.

rows.title: Relationship Events (Lostbelt)
rows.titleText: What did you do prior to the event of Grand Order. This will affect your relationship with the other player in your story. You can choose 3.

Lostbelt: Greek Lostbelt
