Lostbelt: South American Lostbelt

rows.title: Adversaries (Crypters)
Adversaries (Apostles)
Adversaries (Other)

objects.title: Crypter's Round Table
objects.text: You stay loyal to your Fellow Team A, the bond you made when you still in Chaldea still strong. You seek for other way to win without clashing each Lostbelts

objects.title: Eyes of The Apostle
objects.text: Despite being Crypter, your loyaltly lies within the Alien God that you might as well been the eight apostles. You reported each movement made by the Crypters and Chaldea to them.

objects.title: On Humanity Side
objects.text: You stayed loyal to the side of Human Order. When Chaldea arrive you wouldn't oppose them and may instead help them with their quest.

objects.title: On Lostbelt Side
objects.text: You are loyal to your Lostbelt King and/or their Inhabitants. You will seek to turn your Lostbelt into reality and oppose the rest who seek to remove it, be it Chaldea, The Alien God, or other Crypters.

objects.title: Nobody but my own
objects.text: You are loyal to nobody. Not with the Crypter, Apostles or Chaldea and instead decides to do your own thing with your own rules.

rows.title: Faction
rows.titleText: Which Faction are you aligned to

objects.title: Kadoc Zemlupus
objects.text:
Crypter of Russian Lostbelt and Master of Anastasia.

A silver-haired and slim young boy from Poland which joined Chaldea due to his capability to be a master. After he joined the A-Team, his pride feelings of inferiority became even stronger, as all his colleagues were first-class geniuses. 

Even so, he chose to whole-heartedly do his best to protect the Human Order, but his inferiority complex grew even larger after everything was rendered meaningless by Lev Lainur Flauros sabotage and being brought back by the Alien God.

objects.title: Ophelia Phamrsolone
objects.text:
Crypter of Scandinavian Lostbelt and Master of Sigurd

A girl who was born to the prominent Phamrsolone Magus Family in Germany, where her birth parents put her under immense pressure to become a first rate Magus through any means necessary. During her childhood her parents subjected her through several, incredibly painful magical operations in order to increase her overall abilities which left deep emotional trauma. Coupled with their magus mindset of obsessively pursuing the Truth, Ophelia did not receive much emotional support or love from them. As a result of this, Ophelia is incredibly shy and lacks self-confidence.

objects.title: Akuta Hinako
objects.text:
Crypter of Chinese Lostbelt and Master of Lanling Wang

A girl shrouded in mystery and no one really knows about. She seems to dislike people and avoid talking to them. She is someone who would be happy just reading books all day long in the shade. From Chaldea Report, she was a magus that's enrolled in the Clock Tower Botany faculty and later became a technician for Chaldea. 

She was then personally chosen by Director Marisbury Animusphere as a member of the A-Team after her talent was discovered. Due to unknown reason, she often avoids medical examinations conducted by Romani Archaman.

objects.title: Scandinavia Peperoncino
objects.text:
Crypter of Indian Lostbelt and Master of Ashvattman

Real name Arou Myourenji, He was a Japanese magus who practiced Shugendō; more specifically, tengu arts. It was a school of Shugendō that took corrupting into a tengu and finding one's way to hell as a premise. 

Changing his name to Scandinavia Peperoncino and becoming a freelancer, he was recruited to Chaldea after Marisbury Animusphere met Scandinavia during his travels.

objects.title: Kirschtaria Wodime
objects.text:
Leader of Team A, Crypter of Atlantis Lostbelt and Master of Caenis & Dioscuri

Kirschtaria Wodime was born into a thousand-year-old Magi lineage and is the head of the Wodime family. His father tried to have him assassinated sometime in his teens, that although unsuccessful, did end up permanently damaging his Magic Circuits. 

However, despite this normally crippling injury inflicted on him that would have destroyed most Magus's ability to perform Magecraft, Kirstcharia still retained his immense ability and latent talent in the art and was still deemed to be one of the best in the world.

objects.title: Beryl Gut
objects.text:
Crypter of British Lostbelt and Master of Morgan.

A mage from the Department of Botany at the Clock Tower. Although not renowned, he comes from an ancient family line. He was raised by his mother, a Witch, in the forest away from human civilization. During his childhood, he would learn magecraft specifically tailored for assassination, torture, and murder. 

Eventually, when his mother ran out of things to teach him, he killed her and went to the city, where he became both a serial killer and an assassin. He is infamous for being a criminal, and a murderer who kills just for fun.

objects.title: Daybit Sem Void
objects.text:
Crypter of American Lostbelt and Master of Tezcatlipoca

Daybit was a magus who once enrolled in the Clock Tower's Department of Lore, and while it was publicly rumored that he was expelled from the Department, he actually left voluntarily to join the Chaldea Security Organization. 

Rather than being invited by Marisbury Animusphere, he arrived of his own initiative upon hearing of Marisbury’s research and interest in his background. Although having belonged to the Department of Lore for 8 years, His records before joining them is non-existent.

rows.title: Crypters Relation
rows.titleText:
Formerly the A-Team of Chaldea handpicked by Marisbury Animusphere. The Crypters are your comrades, at least until each Lostbelts is stabilized. Each of the Crypters has been given their own Lostbelt to manage and although they function as a team, each of them has their own sets of goals and motivation.

By Default they'll have the same Lostbelt and Servants compared to the original, but if you took the place through this CYOA. They'll instead manage another Lostbelt that's similar in theme to their original Lostbelt. You also can change their Servant too if you want.

rows.title: Novum Chaldea Relation
rows.titleText: The remnants of the Old Chaldea. Their goal is to solve the mystery of the bleaching of the earth and restore Pan-Human History to it's original state. They will try to destroy the Tree of Emptiness and collapse your Lostbelt.

rows.title: Apostles of the Alien God Relation
rows.titleText: Servants summoned by the Alien World for the purpose of enacting The Human Order Revision Phenomenon. Each of them are High Servant which have some divine spirits forced on their Saint Graph. Their loyalty lies for the Alien God although each of them have their own method and preference on completing their goal.

rows.title: Relationship Boons

objects.title: Total Collapse
objects.text:
The Stability of your Lostbelt dropped too low for too long, and the world finally gave out. The Fantasy Tree couldn’t keep holding up the sky and collapses into itself.

There is no grand battle, no last stand against Chaldea. The land folds in on itself, your people vanish without even becoming a footnote, and you are dragged down with it. Your Lostbelt is erased quietly and completely, treated as a failed branch that never had a chance to exist.

objects.title: Consumed by The Tree
objects.text:
You were to greedy and took too much from the Fantasy Tree, much more than your body and spirit were ever meant to handle. Its power began to corrupt your body.

By the time you realized what was happening, your soul and the Tree’s core had already started to fuse. You don’t die in any normal sense, you simply stop being a person. When it’s over, a new Fantasy Tree stands where you once did, roots sunk deep into the Lostbelt, as if this had always been its true shape.

objects.title: Cosmos Denial
objects.text:
After a long and gruesome campaign, Chaldea finally reaches the heart of your Lostbelt. The last defenses fall, your Servants are pushed back or defeated, and the Tree of Emptiness stands exposed to the one group designed to kill it. They do not hesitate.

The Tree is destroyed, and with it the foundation of your entire world. Land, people, history, and even the sky are peeled away and overwritten by Proper Human History’s “correct” record. For Chaldea, this is another necessary victory on the road to saving the Human Order. For you and your Lostbelt, it is simple erasure. No paradise, no afterlife, just a confirmation that this branch was never meant to exist.

objects.title: New History
objects.text:
Chaldea loses. Whether through careful planning, raw power, luck, or all three, they fail to destroy your Fantasy Tree. Your Lostbelt holds together under its own rules, its people survive, and the world accepts this branch as something more than a temporary error.

You don’t get much time to celebrate. Beyond your borders, other Lostbelts have also weathered the storm, and their Trees are still standing. The war between surviving branches begins: each world fighting to overwrite the others and become the standard for all human history. The outcome will decide what “Humanity” means from now on.

objects.title: On Dream's End
objects.text: A Calamity starting from your Lostbelt escapes the boundaries of your world and reaches Proper Human History. It's now on it's way to cause the same thing that happened to your Lostbelt to the rest of the earth. Things can't be bleaker.

objects.title: Heroic Sacrifice
objects.text: You Sacrificed yourself to stop a Calamity from manifesting in Proper Human History. You entrust your goal to Chaldea and the last master of humanity as you take your last breath. Maybe the Throne of Heroes will recognize your heroic deeds and allow Chaldea to summon you as a Pseudo-Servant

objects.title: Redemption Arc
objects.text:
Your Lostbelt collapses, and for a moment it seems like you are going to disappear with it. Instead, Novum Chaldea reaches out, not to finish you off, but to pull you aboard. Maybe as a prisoner or a possible asset. At first, every conversation is an interrogation and every kindness is carefully measured.

Time passes. You slowly start helping them survive the next fights. Suspicion fades into wary respect, then into something like trust. By the time their journey continues, you’re not just a rescued enemy. You’re an emergency backup for the Last Master of Humanity, someone they can rely on if the worst happens.

objects.title: Novum Chaldea
objects.text:
After a long and brutal conflict, you, your Lostbelt King, and Chaldea reach an agreement: instead of destroying your world, they will use it as a base of operations while they fight the remaining Lostbelts and the Alien God.

Your land becomes a strange kind of stronghold, half-refuge and half-military outpost. Chaldea’s staff and Servants operate under the watchful eyes of your people and your king, and in return your Lostbelt gains protection, information, and a chance to influence the shape of the coming battles. The Human Order is still on the line, but now you’re fighting alongside them instead of against them.

objects.title: Envoy of a Dead World
objects.text:
When your Lostbelt finally collapses, you manage to escape before the pruning phenomenon wipes you out along with everyone else. Another Lostbelt takes you in, and you stand on foreign soil as a guest instead of an enemy.

You are safe, for now. Your status is uncertain: part advisor, part hostage, part reminder of what awaits any world that fails to protect its Tree. Whether this new Lostbelt becomes the new history or simply another branch to be pruned, remains to be seen.

objects.title: Patchwork Human Order
objects.text: Chaldea falls, and Proper Human History loses its strongest defender. With that obstacle gone, your attention turns to the other Crypters and their worlds. Instead of trying to annihilate each other outright, you manage to broker an uneasy agreement: combine strength first, fight each other later. Several Lostbelts begin the process of merging their resources to stand against the Alien God and the Apostles. Your story doesn’t end with a single world winning; it continues in a patchwork reality where multiple failed histories have decided to risk everything together rather than die alone.

objects.title: Apostle of Alien World
objects.text: You die when your Lostbelt goes down, but your story doesn’t stop there. The Alien World reviews your actions and decides that, despite everything, you’re still useful. Instead of letting you vanish, they rebuild you as an Apostle, stitching together your spirit with the abilities of your Servants and fragments of Divine Spirit Saint Graphs. You return not as a Crypter, but as something closer to a High-Servant, carrying power and authority you never had in life. Your orders now come from beyond any human nation or history, and sooner or later, your path will cross Chaldea’s again. This time, you won’t be fighting to protect a single Lostbelt; you’ll be enforcing the will of the Alien World itself.

objects.title: Capital of New Earth
objects.text:
After Chaldea is defeated, the Alien God does more than simply spare your Lostbelt—it chooses it. Your world is selected as the ideal stage for the next era, and the Alien God descends to make it their permanent residence. The announcement is simple: this Lostbelt is now the Capital of New Earth.

After Chaldea is defeated, the Alien God does more than simply spare your Lostbelt—it chooses it. Your world is selected as the ideal stage for the next era, and the Alien God descends to make it their permanent residence. The announcement is simple: this Lostbelt is now the Capital of New Earth.

objects.title: Gravekeeper of the Lost World
objects.text:
When Chaldea cut down your Tree, when Human Order moved to prune your world, you chose your Lostbelt over everything. With some Faustian Bargain, you poured every last drop of mana, prayer, and hatred into the Fantasy Tree and told it to live. It listened. Your world, your people, the land itself fused with the Tree’s will, and you with it resulted in an unkillable engine of rejection.

To The Human Order, you are no longer a human. You are a calamity: a storm of thorns that crawls along the edge of reality, with burning hatred for Proper Human History.

objects.title: Crown of a Counterfeit Sky
objects.text:
Chaldea falls, the Alien God turns its gaze elsewhere, and the other Crypters tear at each other.  The King, or the one who inherited that crown, recognizes who kept this fractured sky from collapsing. You are no mere observer or caretaker now. You are the shield and the sword of a world that should not exist, the one who carved out a place in history by sheer stubbornness.

The Human Order will call your home a “mistake,” a “branch that should have been pruned.” It doesn’t matter. For the people who live under your rejected sky, you are the proof that they were worth saving.

objects.title: King of Ashes
objects.text:
Victory looks different when you never meant to share it. 

While the Crypters gambled worlds against each other, while Chaldea bled itself dry for a “correct” future, while the Alien God watched and weighed, you played a smaller, sharper game.

In the final collapse, Your Tree didn't stands proud above a thriving world. Rather, It is a world born from mutual assured destruction. The Lostbelt King is gone, sacrificed, betrayed, or simply outplayed. The other factions are broken beyond recognition. And on a throne built from countless of death, you sit alone. No banner. No allies. No rivals left strong enough to matter.

You are the King of Ashes.

rows.title: Ending
rows.titleText: How do you end up?

defaultRowText: This is a row, and inside of it, you can place choices. On both rows and choices Requirements can be placed, which will block a row from being viewed, or make the player unable to select a choice, depending on either Point-types or the Ids of other choices. Point-types can be made in Features then Manage Points. Hovering over buttons will explain what they do. The Design of the project can be changed in 'Modify Design' at the side navigation bar, and private styling for each row can be turned on in the rows Settings. Default text like this can be turned off in Features -> Manage Defaults.
defaultChoiceText: This is a Choice, and inside of it, you can place images and text. Scores can be added to it, and have Point-types attached. Addons can be added underneath the image and text. In the Functions at the bottom of the choice, there is an array of different things that can be done. Default text like this can be turned off in Features then Manage Defaults.

Lorem Ipsum has been the industry's standard dummy text ever since the 1500s, when an unknown printer took a galley of type and scrambled it to make a type specimen book. It has survived not only five centuries, but also the leap into electronic typesetting, remaining essentially unchanged. It was popularised in the 1960s with the release of Letraset sheets containing Lorem Ipsum passages, and more recently with desktop publishing software like Aldus PageMaker including versions of Lorem Ipsum.
